text: Scotland is a world of poetic words. My mum said of my brother "he'd fall in the Clyde and come out with his pockets full of salmon"

3 of my favourites from my parents: Never pack a gobshite- you can always find one when you get there; it’s hard to tell if he’s fast asleep or slow awake; and, that fucker wouldn’t lift a coal off your foot.
My Scottish friend calls that an elephant bagger: if you have an elephant, he has the bag it goes in.

Multilingual Poem, Pt 2

English cheese is good
Dutch cheese is gouda
 
An English sweater is soft
A Japanese one is ichi
 
In the UK you gently turn a tap
In the US you faucet
 
An English please is sour
A German please is bitte
 
English thank yous kill with kindness
In France it’s a merci killing
When French chefs have to move to a new kitchen, they often lose their huile d’olive

If you visit an English bread museum, nothing bad will happen
But if you visit a French one, you'll end up in a world of pain
In England ladders are quite heavy, but in Germany they are Leiter

If you visit an English bread museum, nothing bad will happen
But if you visit a French one, you'll end up in a world of pain

The English love their cars to a ridiculous degree 
But Germans just take it to fahr

English thank yous can kill you with kindness
But for the French, it would be a merci killing

An Englishman's gift
Is a German's poison

And in France one man's fish
Is another man’s poisson

English baths are lovely
But German baths are Bad
An English person sometimes feels a sense of dread after intercourse, but in German fear comes before sex

English weather is wet
But German weather is Wetter
 
English children are kind
But German kids are Kinder
 
English mothers mumble
But German mothers Mutter
 
The English shout the word people
But Germans just quietly Menschen it
 
And English sausages can be bad
But a German sausage is the Wurst

A Welsh version of “a leopard never changes its spots” is a ddwg ŵy a ddwg fwy. It means “he who steals an egg will steal more”

A Welsh version of “to carry coals to Newcastle” is rho(dd)i pwltis ar goes bren or “to put poultice on a wooden leg”. Another couple of phrases about doing something pointless are iro hwch â bloneg (“to grease a sow with fat”) and golchi traed alarch (“to wash a swan’s feet”)
A Welsh phrase for an average person (or an equivalent to “the Man on the Clapham Omnibus”) is “Mrs Jones from Llanrug” (an imagined typical audience member of Radio Cymru)
A poetic Welsh phrase for describing pregnancy is mae hi'n magu mân esgyrn. It means “she’s rearing tiny bones”
There are several Welsh names for a woodlouse, my two favourites being twrch coed, which means “tree hog”, and gwrach y lludw, which means “witch of the ashes” (or “sorceress of the dust”)

The standard Welsh word for a jellyfish is sglefren fôr (essentially “slippy sea thing”). A slang name for them (cue debate over whether any Welsh person has ever said it) is pysgod wibli wobli (“wibbly wobbly fish”). A more popular slang name is cont y môr, or “cünt of the sea”

There’s a Welsh word for a laptop, gliniadur, that combines glin, which is a shortened version of penglin (knee) and iadur, which is derived from cyfrifiadur (computer). So essentially a “kneeputer”. Another Welsh word for a laptop is sgrin-ar-lin, or “screen-on-the-knees”
A Welsh way of saying something is not right (or “I smell a rat”) is mae rhyw ddrwg yn y caws. It means “there’s some badness in the cheese”

France gave it back (to Italy at least) in their own early name for it. I had a list of them in the first book, and similarly a list of different versions of "it's all Greek to me" (in both books, but the most recent one was more relevant in containing exclusively international finger pointing)...

A Polish term for the type of industrial action where you go slow or work to rule is “an Italian strike”. An Italian term for using a service without paying is “being Portuguese”. And a Portuguese phrase for something done merely for appearances is “for the English to see”

A Russian term for the uncomfortable feeling of watching someone embarrass themselves is “Spanish shame”. A Spanish term for playing dumb to avoid responsibility is “pretending to be Swedish”. And a Swedish term for a chaotic meeting with no resolution is “a Polish parliament”
In French, a wrench is often referred to as an "English key", while in Romanian it can be known as a "French key". In Danish the wrench is often referred to as a svensknøgle (a Swedish key)

A Norwegian name for an on/off or reset switch (or any solution so straightforward even a dimwit can use it) is “a Swedish button”. An old Swedish name for a plastic bag is “a Polish attaché case”. And a very old Polish phrase for a bad situation is “fucked up like in a Russian tank”

These are good! Some Finnish alternatives include rähmäkäpälä, 'gunk paw', which should be part of the official language test, pronunciation-wise. 

And there's of course mämmikoura, 'mämmi fist/hand'. What's this mämmi I hear you ask? Well,
A slang Czech phrase to describe someone who’s trying to use a tool or instrument in an ungainly way is držíš to jak prase kost. It means “you’re holding it like a pig would hold a bone”

A Chilean phrase for someone who breaks everything they touch is tener manos de hacha (“to have hatchet hands”). A similar term from Mexican slang is manos de estomago. It means “stomach hands” (because their hands, like the stomach / intestines, turns everything to shıt)
Another Finnish word for someone prone to dropping things is nakkisormi, which means “wiener finger”

A rhyming version of “speak of the devil and he shall appear” from Ireland is “speak of an ass and he’s sure to pass”. Or, in Irish Gaelic you could say tagann gach aon rud lena iomrá ach madadh rua agus marbhán. It means “everything comes when it’s talked about, except a fox and a corpse”

A Finnish version of “speak of the devil and he appears” is “the evil is where it is mentioned”. The phrase in Finnish is siinä paha missä mainitaan, which is sometimes playfully spoonerised to siinä maha missä painitaan (“the belly is where the wrestling is happening”)
A Swedish version of “speak of the devil and he shall appear” is när man talar om trollen, så står de i farstun. It means “when you speak of the trolls, they stand in the entrance hall”

A Russian version of “no use crying over spilt milk” is снявши голову, по волосам не плачут, which means “no use crying over lost hair when your head’s been cut off.” Finnish has a version that translates to “it doesn’t help crying in the market.” And Turkish has “it’s as small as a seed from a fig”

If you were looking for a proverbial equivalent that expresses the same idea as crying over spilt milk I’d say the two closest are either le deuil de l’eau renversée ne vaut rien (and several other languages have a version of the idiom with water instead of milk) or simply ne pleure pas sur ton sort

Danish has several great words for a jellyfish. A non-stinging jellyfish is vandman, which means “water man”. A stinging jellyfish is called brandman, or “fire man”. And then there’s the general term gople, which derives from the Norwegian dialect word gopla. It essentially means “mass of slime”
If you’re claiming Drowned Ghost Vomit I’ll have Mush Fish (from my other post)

The standard Welsh word for a jellyfish is sglefren fôr, which essentially means “slippy sea thing.” A slang name for them (cue debate over whether any Welsh person has ever said it) is pysgod wibli wobli, or “wibbly wobbly fish.” A more popular slang name is cont y môr. It means “c*nt of the sea”

The standard word for a jellyfish in Norwegian is “manet,” from the Old Norse marnæta, which means “sea-nettle,” a fairly evocative name. But it’s nothing compared to an old Norwegian dialect word for jellyfish, “draugspy,” which essentially means “vomit from the ghost of a drowned person”

In most Latin American Spanishes instead of “cheese” you’d say “whiskey” when having a photo taken. In Spain, ¡patata! (potato!) is more common.
